captions.text:
Hi my name's Elizabeth and I'm speaking on
behalf of expert village. What we're going

to talk today is birds that bite. The number
one reason that most parrots bite is out of

fear. So if your bird is biting the number
one way for you to get your bird to stop biting

is to figure out why your bird is biting and
change it so you're no longer threatening

this animal and he's no longer frightened.
Your obviously pushing yourself on this bird

or he's frightened or something is very uncomfortable
that this is the last form of self defense.

Most birds in the wild would just choose to
fly away versus aggressively biting you. So

most birds when they bite is like a dog that
bites, they feel cornered. So you need to

find a way to make this experience more comfortable.
If you have a bird that bites and you and

you wanna get a particular behavior out of
him such as step up or if you've got them

already on your hand. Come here Karen step
up, good girl. Let's say for instance Karen

wanted to bite me and I was about to just
do something like say step up and instead

of stepping up, sorry, she switched and she
decided that she wanted to bite my hand so

what I would do is just as she was reaching
 , sorry, I'm sorry, as she was reaching for

her beak what I'd do is I'd wobble my hand
ever so slightly just like this as she's reaching

to bite. What that does is it's a negative
reinforcement they don't like losing their

balance and so it'll stop the biting behavior.
You can do this two or three times until you

can offer your hand and she no longer tries
to bite before standing up onto the next hand.

That's one way to start, just keep them from
biting from one hand to the next. Again that's

not a way of causing it to be a more positive
experience but immediately it can keep you

from getting bitten. The other way again is
to reach from behind the bird. The last method

to keep from biting is to obviously just offer
a distraction at the same time. So if Karen

wanted to bite what I would do is I'd say
step up and at the same time, sorry my birds

can fly so they can choose to not interact
with me. You'd offer a distraction so if I

was going to ask her to step up at the same
time I'd offer her to step up I'd offer a

distraction at the same time this can be a
piece of a popsicle stick or a piece of food

and ask them to do he two activities simultaneously.
So you'll offer food while while offering

your hand. This often times is distracting
enough to break the bite behavior. So there's

different ways to stop biting the number one
way is to distract and the other number one

way would be to figure out why the bird wants
to bite you in the first place and change

up their environment. Try to create the situation
in such a way that is positive and the bird

wants to interact so that he doesn't want
to bite you instead.

title: How to Train a Parrot : How to Train Parrots to Stop Biting

comments.text:
I'm not questioning your parrot knowledge... but if you're going to do 
videos on training birds, you should edit/fix/and do what is necessary so 
you actually look competent in it. 

I just can't believe you'd do a video giving advice on parrots when your so 
nervous you cause the parrot to lose balance twice, have a plucking 
cockatoo in the background, and the bird takes off halfway through the 
video because it doesn't want you touching it. I'm not saying those things 
don't happen, but you're in control of the play and pause button and you 
chose the take you decided to put online. 

Otherwise it just epitomizes the parrot industry in general. People with a 
barely half working knowledge of how to take care of parrots thinking 
they're "trainers" because they've had a parrot for two years and giving 
new pet owners crappy advice, then hoarding more animals than they can 
handle and calling it "humane".﻿

comments.text:
The bird in the background is only
molting, adults do this about once a year to renew old worn out feathers. 
It is no sign whatsoever of poor health. :) just so people don't keep 
asking what's up with the bird in the back. Some birds molt worse than 
others and some look pretty bad when they molt. One of mine molts and looks 
real bad but he's perfectly healthy ﻿
comments.author: Liam Houghton

comments.text:
The bird in the background is feather plucking.  Molting is much more 
gradual.  It is incorrect advice that this is a molt.  I hope this bird has 
seen an avian vet to uncover what may be causing this self-destructive 
behavior.

comments.author: mel01777

comments.text:
GIve him an option that he wants. For example, hold a peanut or some other 
favorite treat in the other hand while gradually putting your hand in a 
spot inbetween your shoulder and the treat. Also, birds prefer to move UP, 
so you could always put a small ladder on your shoulder (with a nut on top) 
to get him used to walking up it as you say 'up'. This has worked for me 
with a cockatiel.
comments.author: Deb B

comments.author: nita007@yahoo.com girl

comments.text:
So sorry to hear that. I have a bird who barks too. Grays only have to hear 
something ONCE to remember it and learn it, and once they've learned it, if 
they like the sound, they will never forget. You now have a guard dog (if 
it's the sound of a big dog) or a toy (if it's a little yappy mutt). Just 
don't feed him dog food.
comments.author: Deb B

comments.text:
I have an african grey, and he started biting me after I got a haircut some 
days ago. My hair was pretty lengthy (was growing for about 3 years), and 
the moment I arrived back home his behaviour changed. Does anyone have an 
idea to solve this situation, or just answer why does he do this now? Is it 
because he doesn't recognize me anymore?﻿
comments.author: janosiadam

comments.text:
Thank you for the advice. By the time he has changed back to his older 
self. He got used to the new haircut. :)
comments.author: janosiadam

comments.text:
Pretty obvious, you've changed your appearance and it has upset your bird. 
Grays are very sensitive to their environment, ANY change can make them 
scared. It's something genetic, and by being that way it helped them avoid 
dangerous things. Give your bird time to adjust to you.

comments.author: Fernanda Garza

comments.text:
+Vinod Balakrishnan Oh my, I'm so sorry to hear. I'm no expert in this, I 
only know by experience I've had with my cockatiel. When he is biting 
something he is not supposed to, I've heard you need to give him 
distraction. Something he can chew instead, since that's probably what they 
lack. They could also be bored and don't know the rules. Don't yell or be 
aggressive, it'll make them stress out and anxious (not saying you do that, 
but in case you don't know!). Does he have parrot toys? Have you done 
research on the internet about the parrot you have?
Also, when he goes somewhere he isn't allowed to (curtains he poops on), 
just calmly move him elsewhere. He may learn that way it is not a place for 
him to sit on. Have also places for him to go, such as parrot stands ( 
https://www.google.fi/search?q=parrot+tree&source=lnms&tbm=isch&sa=X&ei=zAZtU_8rpovJA9qxgNAE&ved=0CAYQ_AUoAQ&biw=1366&bih=643#q=parrot+stand&tbm=isch&imgdii=59n2D2G_9diEsM%3A%3ByBbwAq2iCVOd5M%3B59n2D2G_9diEsM%3A 
) where he'll learn to be and chill. Only on the cage gets really boring.
But yeah, I'm really no expert, I'd suggest you google some ring neck 
parrot sites where their general personalities and needs are listed, and 
given help and information to the owners!
comments.author: LadyDynamitez

comments.author: Fernanda Garza

comments.text:
Do you use the cage as a punishment (do you put him in there after he's 
done something wrong)? Putting the bird in the cage shouldn't be 
uncomfortable for the bird because it's the place he should feel the most 
safe and calm. I put my birdie in his cage only when it's time to sleep or 
when I'm going out for longer time (work, school, etc.). My mom used to use 
his cage as a punishment so putting him in the cage used to be much more 
difficult.
comments.author: LadyDynamitez

Give him some freedom :) if they wanna be in the cage they go back and when 
they are tired they will want to go in or need water/food

wobbling hand is NOT "negative reinforcement - it is punishment by 
definition: anything that reduces behavior. That bird is not comfortable

fluttering wings when stepping up (preparing for aversive hand wobble???) 
3. flies away when approached with ball on rod. This bird has been exposed 
to many aversive actions -I would NEVER trust this person to train MY 
birds, especially a bird that requires behavior modification.

comments.author: purpleandguineapigs

comments.text:
I can safely say that this is not the case. Yes parrots molt and lose 
feathers - but the old feathers instantly get replaced. When my parrot 
molts he just looks a little fluffier and his cage and the ground will be 
covered with a mountain of feathers! But they will never grow bald or lose 
their ability to fly. The bird you see in the video probably mutilated 
himself, which is something parrots do when they are neglected, and these 
people probably adopted him.

luck!
